HowToPray.title: How to Pray the Rosary
HowToPray.subtitle: Step-by-step guide to praying the Holy Rosary
HowToPray.intro: The Rosary is more than a series of prayers ‚Äî it is a contemplative meditation on the life of Christ through the eyes of Mary. Each mystery invites us to live our faith more deeply, transforming repetition into contemplation and habit into living love.

needs.title: What you need
items: A rosary (beads) or your fingers for counting

step1.title: Start with the Sign of the Cross
step1.description: Hold the crucifix and make the sign of the cross while praying:
step1.prayer: "By the sign of the Holy Cross, deliver us from our enemies, O Lord our God. In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit. Amen."

step2.title: Pray the Creed
step2.description: Still at the crucifix, pray the full Apostles' Creed.
step2.linkText: See full text of the Creed

step3.title: Our Father (1x)
step3.description: On the first large bead after the crucifix, pray one Our Father.

step4.title: Hail Mary (3x)
step4.description: On the next three beads, pray three Hail Marys:

step5.title: Glory Be
step5.prayer: "Glory be to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Spirit. As it was in the beginning, is now, and ever shall be. Amen."

step6.title: Announce the First Mystery
step6.description: Announce the first mystery of the day and meditate on it while praying.

step8.title: Repeat for the 5 Mysteries
step8.description: Repeat steps 6 and 7 for each of the five mysteries of the day (total of 5 decades).

step9.title: Finish with the Hail Holy Queen
step9.description: After the five decades, pray the Hail Holy Queen:
step9.prayer: "Hail, Holy Queen, Mother of Mercy, our life, our sweetness and our hope, hail!..."

step10.title: End with the Sign of the Cross
step10.description: Make the sign of the cross to end your rosary prayer.

tips.title: Tips for deep prayer
items: Pray slowly, meditating on each mystery
Choose a fixed time of day to create the habit
Offer your intentions at the beginning of the prayer
Use a religious image or icon to help with concentration

montfort.description: Saint Louis Mary Grignion de Montfort (1673-1716), great apostle of the Rosary, taught a special method to make prayer more contemplative. His method divides each Hail Mary into three parts to deepen the meditation.

items.title: Following Hail Marys: The Virtues
items.description: Contemplate the virtues of Jesus and Mary

items.title: Last Hail Marys: The Application
items.description: Apply the teachings to your life

History.title: History of the Rosary
History.subtitle: The origin and evolution of one of the most beloved prayers
History.intro: For over 800 years, the Rosary has been the prayer of God's people ‚Äî of kings and peasants, of saints and sinners. Knowing its history helps us live this living tradition, understanding that we are part of an uninterrupted chain of faith that crosses centuries.

timeline.title: Ancient Origins
content: Since the first centuries of Christianity, desert monks already used stones or grains to count repetitive prayers. The Desert Fathers recited the 150 Psalms of David as a form of continuous prayer.

For the faithful who did not know how to read or memorize the psalms, the practice of praying 150 Hail Marys (or Our Fathers) arose, using knotted ropes or stones to keep count. This practice became known as the "Mary's Psalter".

timeline.title: Saint Dominic de Guzm√°n
content: According to Catholic tradition, the Virgin Mary appeared to Saint Dominic de Guzm√°n in 1208, during his mission against the Albigensian heresy in southern France. She handed him the Rosary as a powerful weapon against heresies and sin.

Saint Dominic began to preach the Rosary as a form of meditation on the mysteries of the life of Christ, combining vocal prayer with contemplation. He organized the prayer into three groups of five mysteries each: Joyful, Sorrowful, and Glorious.
timeline.quote: "A single Hail Mary well said makes all hell tremble." - Saint Dominic de Guzm√°n

timeline.title: Battle of Lepanto
content: The victory of the Christian fleet over the Ottoman Empire at the Battle of Lepanto is attributed to the intercession of Our Lady of the Rosary. Pope Pius V had asked all Christians to pray the Rosary before the battle.
Against all expectations, the Christian fleet achieved a decisive victory. In gratitude, the Pope instituted the feast of Our Lady of Victories (later called Our Lady of the Rosary) on October 7.
timeline.badge: Feast of Our Lady of the Rosary: October 7

timeline.title: Renewal and Popularization
content: In the 15th century, the Dominican Alan de la Roche worked intensely to renew the devotion to the Rosary, which had diminished. He founded Rosary confraternities and wrote extensively about its spiritual benefits.
Through the Dominicans, the devotion spread rapidly throughout Europe, becoming one of the most popular practices among Catholics of all social classes.

timeline.title: Luminous Mysteries
content: Pope Saint John Paul II, a great devotee of the Rosary, added the Luminous Mysteries (or Mysteries of Light) in the Apostolic Letter "Rosarium Virginis Mariae" in 2002. These new mysteries meditate on the public life of Jesus.
With this addition, the Rosary now has 20 mysteries (previously 15), representing the 200 years since the institution of the feast of Our Lady of the Rosary.
timeline.quote: "The Rosary is my favorite prayer. It is a wonderful prayer. Wonderful in its simplicity and in its depth." - Pope Saint John Paul II

timeline.title: Apparitions of Fatima
content: During the apparitions of Fatima in Portugal, Our Lady insistently asked the three shepherd children to pray the Rosary every day for peace in the world and for the conversion of sinners.
The message of Fatima renewed devotion to the Rosary in the 20th century and continues to inspire millions of Catholics to pray daily.
timeline.quote: "Pray the Rosary every day, to obtain peace for the world and the end of the war." - Our Lady of Fatima, May 13, 1917

timeline.title: The Rosary Today
content: Today, the Rosary remains one of the most practiced devotions by Catholics worldwide. Millions of faithful pray daily, whether in churches, families, individually, or through digital applications and platforms.

The Rosary has transcended generations and cultures, remaining a simple yet profoundly contemplative prayer that unites Catholics in prayer for world peace, the conversion of sinners, and the needs of the Church.

Mysteries.title: Mysteries of the Rosary
Mysteries.subtitle: Meditations on the life of Jesus Christ and Mary
Mysteries.intro: The mysteries of the Rosary are not just historical events to remember ‚Äî they are windows open to contemplate Christ. By meditating on each mystery, we live the faith they reveal, allowing the life of Jesus to transform our own life.

source.label: Official source:
source.base: Based on the Apostolic Letter Rosarium Virginis Mariae by Pope Saint John Paul II (2002)

groups.title: The Four Groups of Mysteries
groups.description: The complete Rosary is composed of 20 mysteries divided into four groups. The indication of the days is not mandatory and can be adapted according to spiritual and pastoral needs (Rosarium Virginis Mariae, 38).

items.title: The Annunciation of the Angel to Mary
items.quote: In the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a city of Galilee named Nazareth, to a virgin betrothed to a man whose name was Joseph, of the house of David; and the virgin's name was Mary.

items.title: The Visitation of Mary to Elizabeth
items.quote: In those days Mary arose and went with haste into the hill country, to a city of Judah, and she entered the house of Zechariah and greeted Elizabeth.

items.title: The Birth of Jesus in Bethlehem
items.quote: And while they were there, the time came for her to be delivered. And she gave birth to her first-born son and wrapped him in swaddling cloths, and laid him in a manger.

items.title: The Presentation of Jesus in the Temple
items.quote: And when the time came for their purification according to the law of Moses, they brought him up to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord.

items.title: The Finding of Jesus in the Temple
items.quote: After three days they found him in the temple, sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking them questions.

luminosos.title: Luminous Mysteries
luminosos.subtitle: The Public Life of Jesus
luminosos.note: Introduced by Saint John Paul II in 2002 (Rosarium Virginis Mariae)

items.title: The Baptism of Jesus in the Jordan
items.quote: And when Jesus was baptized, he went up immediately from the water, and behold, the heavens were opened and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove, and alighting on him.

items.title: The Wedding at Cana
items.quote: His mother said to the servants, 'Do whatever he tells you.'

items.title: The Proclamation of the Kingdom of God
items.quote: The time is fulfilled, and the kingdom of God is at hand; repent, and believe in the gospel.

items.title: The Transfiguration of Jesus
items.quote: And he was transfigured before them, and his face shone like the sun, and his garments became white as light.

items.title: The Institution of the Eucharist
items.quote: Now as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed, and broke it, and gave it to the disciples and said, 'Take, eat; this is my body.'

items.title: The Agony of Jesus in the Garden
items.quote: My Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me; nevertheless, not as I will, but as thou wilt.

items.title: The Scourging of Jesus at the Pillar
items.quote: Then he released for them Barabbas, and having scourged Jesus, delivered him to be crucified.

items.title: The Crowning with Thorns
items.quote: And plaiting a crown of thorns they put it on his head, and put a reed in his right hand. And kneeling before him they mocked him, saying, 'Hail, King of the Jews!'

items.title: The Carrying of the Cross
items.quote: And they compelled a passer-by, Simon of Cyrene, who was coming in from the country, to carry his cross. And they brought him to the place called Golgotha.

items.title: The Crucifixion and Death of Jesus
items.quote: Father, into thy hands I commit my spirit! And having said this he breathed his last.

gloriosos.title: Glorious Mysteries
gloriosos.subtitle: The Glory of Christ and Mary

items.title: The Resurrection of Jesus
items.quote: Why do you seek the living among the dead? He is not here, but has risen.

items.title: The Ascension of Jesus into Heaven
items.quote: So then the Lord Jesus, after he had spoken to them, was taken up into heaven, and sat down at the right hand of God.

items.title: The Descent of the Holy Spirit
items.quote: And there appeared to them tongues as of fire, distributed and resting on each one of them. And they were all filled with the Holy Spirit.

items.title: The Assumption of Mary into Heaven
items.quote: For behold, henceforth all generations will call me blessed; for he who is mighty has done great things for me.

items.title: The Coronation of Mary as Queen of Heaven and Earth
items.quote: And a great portent appeared in heaven, a woman clothed with the sun, with the moon under her feet, and on her head a crown of twelve stars.

Prayers.title: Traditional Prayers
Prayers.subtitle: The essential prayers for praying the Holy Rosary
Prayers.intro: Each prayer of the Rosary carries centuries of devotion and spiritual wisdom. Knowing its deep meaning allows us to live the prayer not as mechanical repetition, but as an intimate dialogue with God through Mary.

source.label: Official source:
source.standard: Official English translations following Vatican standards

Prayers.introduction: These are the official prayers that make up the Holy Rosary according to the tradition of the Catholic Church. Learn them by heart to be able to pray with devotion and deep meditation. Click the copy button to save each prayer.

list.title: Sign of the Cross
list.subtitle: Beginning and end of the Rosary
list.text:
In the name of the Father,
and of the Son,
and of the Holy Spirit.
Amen.

list.title: Apostles' Creed
list.subtitle: Prayed on the crucifix ‚Äî Symbol of the Apostles
list.text:
I believe in God, the Father almighty,
Creator of heaven and earth,

and in Jesus Christ, his only Son, our Lord,
who was conceived by the Holy Spirit,
born of the Virgin Mary,
suffered under Pontius Pilate,
was crucified, died and was buried;
he descended into hell;
on the third day he rose again from the dead;
he ascended into heaven,
and is seated at the right hand of God the Father almighty;
from there he will come to judge the living and the dead.

I believe in the Holy Spirit,
the holy catholic Church,
the communion of saints,
the forgiveness of sins,
the resurrection of the body,
and life everlasting.
Amen.

list.title: Our Father
list.subtitle: The Lord's Prayer ‚Äî before each decade
list.text:
Our Father, who art in heaven,
hallowed be thy name;
thy kingdom come,
thy will be done
on earth as it is in heaven.

Give us this day our daily bread,
and forgive us our trespasses,
as we forgive those who trespass against us;
and lead us not into temptation,
but deliver us from evil.
Amen.

list.title: Hail Mary
list.subtitle: Angelic Salutation ‚Äî ten times in each decade
list.text:
Hail Mary, full of grace,
the Lord is with thee.
Blessed art thou among women,
and blessed is the fruit of thy womb, Jesus.

Holy Mary, Mother of God,
pray for us sinners,
now and at the hour of our death.
Amen.

list.title: Glory Be
list.subtitle: Lesser Doxology ‚Äî after each decade
list.text:
Glory be to the Father,
and to the Son,
and to the Holy Spirit.

As it was in the beginning,
is now, and ever shall be,
world without end.
Amen.

list.title: Fatima Prayer
list.subtitle: Jaculatory ‚Äî after each Glory Be
list.text:
O my Jesus,
forgive us our sins, save us from the fires of hell;
lead all souls to heaven,
especially those in most need
of thy mercy.
list.note: This prayer was taught by Our Lady to the three shepherd children of Fatima on July 13, 1917, after the vision of hell.

list.title: Hail Holy Queen
list.subtitle: Salve Regina ‚Äî at the end of the Rosary
list.text:
Hail, holy Queen, Mother of mercy,
our life, our sweetness and our hope.

To thee do we cry,
poor banished children of Eve.

To thee do we send up our sighs,
mourning and weeping in this valley of tears.

Turn then, most gracious advocate,
thine eyes of mercy toward us.

And after this our exile,
show unto us the blessed fruit of thy womb, Jesus.

O clement, O loving, O sweet Virgin Mary.

V. Pray for us, O holy Mother of God.
R. That we may be made worthy of the promises of Christ.

Amen.

list.title: Concluding Prayer
list.subtitle: Collect ‚Äî after the Hail Holy Queen
list.text:
O God, whose only-begotten Son,
by his life, death and resurrection,
has purchased for us the rewards of eternal salvation:
grant, we beseech thee,
that meditating on these mysteries
of the most holy Rosary of the Blessed Virgin Mary,
we may imitate what they contain
and obtain what they promise.

Through the same Christ our Lord.
Amen.

structure.title: Structure of the Rosary
structure.vatican: According to the Holy See: "At the beginning of each decade, the mystery to be contemplated is announced. After a brief pause for reflection, the Our Father, ten Hail Marys and the Glory Be are prayed."
items: 4. Three Hail Marys (three small beads) ‚Äî For faith, hope and charity
8. Ten Hail Marys (decade) ‚Äî meditating on the mystery
10. Repeat 6-9 for the other mysteries (total: 5 decades)

About.title: About Living Rosary
About.subtitle: A platform to live your faith, every day

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.p1: Living Rosary makes the teachings of the Catholic Church accessible and practical for modern Catholics. We synthesize official documents from the Holy See, writings of saints, and Catholic theology into clear content that nourishes your prayer life.
mission.p2: We don't offer formal courses‚Äîwe offer a digital companion for your faith journey: track your daily prayer, explore Church teachings whenever you wish, and discover the richness of Catholic tradition at your own pace.
mission.visionDesc: To make the teachings of the Holy See and Catholic tradition as accessible as an app on your phone‚Äîwithout losing depth, without distorting doctrine, just Catholic truth in clear language.

principles.title: Our Principles
principles.subtitle: Six pillars that guide every decision, every feature, every word in Living Rosary

p1.title: Authentic Faith
p1.desc: We connect people to the living tradition of the Catholic Church, rooted in the Rosary prayer as a path of spiritual transformation.

p2.title: Global Community
p2.desc: We create a space where Catholics from all parts of the world pray together, share intentions, and grow spiritually connected.

p3.title: Accessible Teachings
p3.desc: We synthesize Holy See documents, writings of saints, and Catholic theology into clear content‚Äîno courses, just Church wisdom within reach.

p4.title: Sacred Simplicity
p4.desc: We transform technology into a prayer tool, keeping the focus on the essence: personal contact with God and Mary.

p5.title: Faith Integrity
p5.desc: All content is based on the Doctrine of the Catholic Church, validated and guided by solid pastoral principles.

p6.title: Accessibility
p6.desc: Free, open to all, without intrusive ads. Faith should not have economic or digital barriers.

track.title: Track
track.desc: Register your daily rosary, track your consistency streaks, see your spiritual growth reflected in numbers that matter.

explore.title: Explore
explore.desc: Navigate through synthesized Catholic teachings: theology, Church history, lives of saints, sacraments‚Äîall based on official Holy See sources.

pray.title: Pray Well
pray.desc: Access prayer guides, explore different Rosary methods, and discover tools that help you pray with greater devotion and awareness.

connect.title: Connect
connect.desc: Join a global community of Catholics, share prayer intentions, and know that you never pray alone, but with a family of faith.

j1.title: Birth of a Vision
j1.desc: Living Rosary started as a simple idea: a rosary tracker that connected people to their daily faith.

j2.title: From Tracker to Hub
j2.desc: We recognized that Catholics wanted more. Not just tracking‚Äîlearning, growing, and communing in faith.

j3.title: Synthesis of Tradition
j3.desc: Living Rosary becomes an accessible compendium of the Church: we synthesize Holy See documents, teachings of saints, and theology into practical content.

d1.title: Based on Official Sources
d1.desc: All content comes from Holy See documents, the Catechism, writings of recognized saints, and Church-approved theology. We don't invent‚Äîwe synthesize what the Church already teaches.

d2.title: Free Navigation
d2.desc: No mandatory paths or sequential lessons. Explore the teachings you want, when you want‚Äîlike browsing a digital compendium of the Catholic faith.

d3.title: Always Free and Open
d3.desc: Living Rosary is an open-source project driven by faith, not profit. Church teachings belong to everyone‚Äîwe don't charge to access them.

d4.title: No Ads, No Invasive Tracking
d4.desc: Your prayer is sacred. We don't monetize it with targeted ads, sell your data, or create consumer profiles.

q1.q: Why do I need to create an account if the service is free?
q1.a: Great question! We ask for a simple account (just email and password) for two reasons: to protect the community from spam and to offer personalized features. With an account, you can track your prayer streak, save favorite content, and access exclusive member resources. It also helps us understand which teachings are most useful, improving the service for everyone. We promise never to sell your data or send spam‚Äîyour account is just your gateway to a richer experience.

q2.q: What can I access without an account? What needs registration?
q2.a:
Without account (public): How to Pray, History of the Rosary, Daily Mysteries, and Traditional Prayers are completely open.

With free account: Streak tracking, full Teachings (saints, theology, sacraments), Prayer Tools, personalized Dashboard, and community access. Creating an account is fast and remains free forever.

q3.q: Is the content really from the Catholic Church?
q3.a: Yes, absolutely. All our content is based on official sources: Catechism of the Catholic Church, papal documents (encyclicals, exhortations), writings of recognized saint doctors, and Holy See-approved theology. We don't create doctrines‚Äîwe just synthesize what the Church has taught for centuries, making it accessible in digital format.

q4.q: Is my data safe? Do you sell information?
q4.a: We never sell data. We collect only the essential: email for login, aggregated (anonymous) usage statistics to improve the service, and your personal preferences (streaks, favorites) stored securely. There are no targeted ads, third-party tracking, or consumer profiles. Your prayer life is private and sacred.

q5.q: Can I use it offline or do I need internet?
q5.a: Currently, Living Rosary requires an internet connection to load content and sync your progress. We are working on offline features (prayer cache, downloaded content) for future versions. For now, a stable connection ensures the best experience.

q6.q: Why is it open source? Can I contribute?
q6.a: Living Rosary is open source because we believe faith tools should be transparent and collaborative. The code is available on GitHub for anyone to review, learn, or contribute. If you are a developer, designer, or Catholic theology expert, your help is welcome! We accept code contributions, content suggestions, and improvements.

q7.q: Is it available in other languages?
q7.a: Currently, Living Rosary is in Portuguese and English. We plan to expand to Spanish and other languages in the future. The infrastructure is prepared for internationalization‚Äîit's just a matter of translating the content while maintaining theological fidelity.

q8.a: For now, Living Rosary works as a web app (PWA - Progressive Web App), accessible via browser on your phone. You can add it to your device's home screen for an experience similar to a native app. Native apps for iOS and Android are on our long-term roadmap.

q9.q: Will it always be free or will it become paid in the future?
q9.a: Living Rosary will always be free. Our commitment is to keep all essential features accessible to all at no cost. In the future, we may introduce optional premium features (like live classes, spiritual consultancies, exclusive content), but the platform's core‚Äîprayer, teachings, and community‚Äîwill remain free.
